item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Fishermen Save 13 From Tourist Boat That Sank
item.description: Rescuers on Monday safely recovered 13 more people from a tourist boat that sank after hitting a reef in central Indonesia but were searching for a Dutch man and an Italian woman who were still missing, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: ‘Security Issues’ Cited in Detention of 3 Journalists
item.description: A Washington Post reporter and two other journalists detained last month are being held over “security issues,” Iran’s judiciary spokesman said Monday, offering the first official indication of why they are being held.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Study Details Elephant Deaths
item.description: Poachers killed an estimated 100,000 elephants across Africa from 2010 to 2012, a huge spike in the continent’s death rate of the world’s largest mammals because of an increased demand for ivory, a study found.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israelis and Palestinians Agree to Lengthen Cease-Fire
item.description: The extension reflects the difficulty of reaching longer agreements after two weeks of talks, but also an apparent lack of appetite on either side to resume conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A Palestinian boy maneuvered Monday through rubble that was once a terminal for a long-defunct airport in Rafah, Gaza.

item.title: Syria’s Chemical Arsenal Fully Destroyed, U.S. Says
item.description: The announcement comes a year after the Assad government used sarin gas to kill more than 1,000 people in Damascus.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: In China, Myths of Social Cohesion
item.description: China’s Communist Party has devoted enormous resources to composing historical narratives, like that of the Fragrant Concubine, that seek to legitimize its rule.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man poses for a picture with a woman dressed as the Fragrant Concubine, left, at the Afaq Khoja Mausoleum.

item.title: Amid Election Impasse, Calls in Afghanistan for an Interim Government
item.description: Several top officials in the government say a ruling committee might be best for now as the candidates in Afghanistan’s recent presidential vote dispute the results.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: The presidential candidates Ashraf Ghani, left, and Abdullah Abdullah, this month at a news conference in Kabul, remain locked in an impasse over who won the Afghan election.

item.title: Troops in Iraq Rout Sunni Militants From a Key Dam
item.description: Kurdish and Iraqi forces took control of the main dam compound, but fighting continued at the site of a separate dam, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER, MARK LANDLER and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga forces took up positions on Monday near the Mosul Dam.

item.title: Daru Journal: Surviving Ebola, but Untouchable Back Home
item.description: As some survivors come back to the world of the living, they feel a chill of wariness, or worse, from neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jattu Lahai, 26, in her room in Daru, Sierra Leone, after completing two weeks of successful treatment for the Ebola virus.

item.title: Rebels Killed Dozens in Attack on Refugees, Ukraine Says
item.description: Ukraine on Monday accused separatists fighters of firing on a caravan of cars carrying refugees, but rebel leaders denied there had been any attack.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER, ANDREW HIGGINS and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A woman and her granddaughter at a refugee camp near Donetsk on Monday.

item.title: Airstrikes Over Tripoli Kill Six; Source of Bombing Is Unknown
item.description: The warplanes struck targets controlled by Islamists, and Libyan authorities attributed the attacks to a foreign state.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY

item.title: Attacks on Aid Workers Jump Worldwide, Group Says
item.description: The sharp rise over the past year and a half reflects a surge in conflict zones.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Saudi Is Robbed in Paris, Quickly and Efficiently
item.description: Eight armed men attacked a convoy as it was heading to Le Bourget airport north of Paris, taking about $335,000 in cash and sensitive diplomatic documents from the Saudi Embassy.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The Four Seasons George V Hotel in Paris, where a Saudi royal was staying before being ambushed Sunday while heading to a local airport.

item.title: Turkey Expresses Outrage at Reports of Routine Spying by Germany, a NATO Ally
item.description: Long angered by allegations of U.S. spying, Germany itself was accused of espionage, including picking up conversations involving Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Julian Assange Says He Will Leave Embassy ‘Soon’
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder has taken refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London for two years while facing extradition to Sweden.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: India Cancels Talks After Pakistani Envoy Meets With Separatists
item.description: In defiance of an Indian warning, a Pakistani diplomat met with Kashmir separatists, dampening hopes that the two nations would resume a peace process.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Son of Jackie Chan Arrested on Drug-related Charges, Chinese Media Report
item.description: Jaycee Chan, who is also an actor, was reportedly arrested along with the Taiwanese actor Ko Chen-tung as part of the crackdown on drugs in China, in which the entertainment industry has seemingly come under particular scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Jaycee Chan, left, with his father, Jackie Chan, at a news conference in Beijing in 2009.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Hong Kong March, Speculation Over Payments and Motivations
item.description: What attracted the most attention in the aftermath of protests against Occupy Central was not the images of trash-strewn streets, but of the messy exchange of money for the apparent drudgery of participating.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Lens Blog: Women Beyond the Veil in Mali
item.description: Katie Orlinsky traveled throughout Mali for almost a month, speaking with women who had lived under Shariah law imposed by Islamic radicals.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By WHITNEY RICHARDSON
item.media:description: Tanti Gassamba lives with her family in a one-room house in Bamako. Tanti was "Miss Timbuktu 2009" in a cultural pageant event organized by her mother, a prominent Timbuktu women's rights activist.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Media Weigh In on Aftermath of Missouri Shooting
item.description: After more than a week of relative silence on the events in Ferguson, Mo., a Xinhua commentary says the violence points to a “human rights flaw” in the United States.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The police in Ferguson, Mo. Officers fired tear gas at demonstrators on Sunday after some of the protesters advanced on a police command center.

item.title: Scores Killed in Flooding in Nepal and India
item.description: More than 11,000 homes have been damaged and roughly 22,000 families displaced in the floods.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: A woman returned by boat after tending her livestock on Monday in the flood-affected Morigaon district of Assam state, India.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Under Beijing’s Eyes
item.description: China keeps secret files on hundreds of millions of its citizens. Mine is full of lies, some of which I made up myself.
item.dc:creator: By MURONG XUECUN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The French Resistance Would Weep
item.description: Seventy years after the liberation of Paris, the ascending force in French politics recalls the spirit of Vichy.
item.dc:creator: By SYLVAIN CYPEL
item.media:description: Resistance fighters manning a barricade in the Rue de la Huchette during the liberation of Paris in August 1944.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: To Aid Kurdistan, Look Beyond Iraq
item.description: To stop ISIS, Washington needs to engage politically with all Kurdish forces, not just the Iraqi ones.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALIZA MARCUS and ANDREW APOSTOLOU

item.title: Britain Says Iraq Campaign Will Last ‘Weeks and Months’
item.description: The defense secretary said the battle against militants had moved beyond a humanitarian effort, but the prime minister said there would be limits to British involvement.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
